Cathedral Church of St John the Divine (NYC)

abstract.p: Footlights column reports on Greatest Hits series at Film Forum, Winter Solstice Celebration at Cathedral Church of St John the Divine, Nutcracker Swing concert by New York Philharmonic and Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall; photos (M)

block.p: Masters' Touch The array of directors includes, among others, Ingmar Bergman, Luis Buñuel, Federico Fellini, Alfred Hitchcock, Stanley Kubrick, Eric Rohmer, Martin Scorsese, François Truffaut and Billy Wilder. The films range from ''Nights of Cabiria'' and ''Raging Bull'' to ''Dr. Strangelove'' and ''The 400 Blows.'' The event is ''Greatest Hits,'' an eight-week, 53-film festival at Film Forum. Running through Feb. 7, the parade begins with Hitchcock's ''Psycho'' and ''The Birds,'' playing on Friday and Saturday.

Masters' Touch The array of directors includes, among others, Ingmar Bergman, Luis Buñuel, Federico Fellini, Alfred Hitchcock, Stanley Kubrick, Eric Rohmer, Martin Scorsese, François Truffaut and Billy Wilder. The films range from ''Nights of Cabiria'' and ''Raging Bull'' to ''Dr. Strangelove'' and ''The 400 Blows.'' The event is ''Greatest Hits,'' an eight-week, 53-film festival at Film Forum. Running through Feb. 7, the parade begins with Hitchcock's ''Psycho'' and ''The Birds,'' playing on Friday and Saturday.

Winter's Return For the 22nd year, the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine will be the site of an ecumenical event that harks back to ancient rituals intended to celebrate the triumph of light over darkness. It is Paul Winter's Winter Solstice Celebration, the cathedral's most popular secular event. This symbolic journey through the longest night of the year toward the return of the sun, represented by a gong seven feet in diameter, features musicians playing from various points and heights. The show includes the Paul Winter Consort, flavored this year by African percussion, singing and dance. Although the winter solstice doesn't arrive until 2:22 p.m. on Dec. 21, these efforts are scheduled for 7:30 p.m. tomorrow and Friday and 2 and 7:30 p.m. on Saturday.

In the Spirit The New York Philharmonic and the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra join forces at 8 p.m. tomorrow at Avery Fisher Hall in a holiday concert, ''Nutcracker Swing.'' In the first part, the combined ensembles, led by Leonard Slatkin, will perform four movements from ''All Rise,'' commissioned by the Philharmonic and composed by the jazz orchestra's artistic director, Wynton Marsalis. In the second part, the Philharmonic will perform movements from Tchaikovsky's ''Nutcracker Suite,'' alternating with the jazz orchestra playing Duke Ellington's and Billy Strayhorn's arrangements. The concert will be repeated at 11 a.m. Friday, 8 p.m. Saturday, 7:30 p.m. Tuesday and 8 p.m. Wednesday.

Footnotes The flutist Paula Robison, accompanied by the harpist Mariko Anraku, will give a free holiday concert at 8 p.m. on Saturday at the Abrons Arts Center at the Henry Street Settlement, 466 Grand Street, on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. . . . Rue McClanahan of ''The Women'' and George Hamilton of ''Chicago,'' joined by performers from virtually every Broadway and Off Broadway show, will light the 2001 Broadway holiday tree at 5:15 tonight in Duffy Square, Broadway at 46th Street, where Police Officer Daniel Rodriguez will sing ''God Bless America.'' The event is free and open to the public.
